title: General Paper 4 FQE (June 2018)
description: Final Qualifying Examination General Paper 4 from June 2018. Contains 30 questions covering Research, Nursing Education, Pediatrics, and Mental Health.

questions.question: Appendices in a research report consist of:

options.text: Data collection instruments, copy of research permit, letters of approval
Copy of research permit, references, histograms
Letters of approval, budget, data collection tool
References, budget, copy of research permit

questions.explanation: Appendices contain supplementary material like tools and permits. References form their own section.

questions.question: The scale measurement with an absolute zero is:
questions.explanation: Ratio scales have a true zero point (e.g., weight, height).

questions.question: Graphic methods of presenting data includes:
questions.explanation: Bar charts, linear graphs, and histograms are standard graphic methods. Frequency tables are tabular.

questions.question: The main sources of hypothesis are:

options.text: Scientific theory, general culture, problem statement

questions.explanation: Hypotheses are derived from theories, experience, literature, and analogies.

questions.question: The following are ethical issues pertaining to research subjects which the researcher is supposed to observe:

options.text: Freedom from harm, plagiarism, informed and voluntary consent
Fraud, freedom from harm, self-respect and dignity
Freedom from harm, informed and voluntary consent, confidentiality

questions.explanation: Beneficence (freedom from harm), Autonomy (consent), and Privacy (confidentiality) are key principles.

questions.question: Indicate whether the following statements regarding teaching are TRUE or FALSE. (Select the TRUE statements)

options.text: Speaking loudly and use of visual aids make teaching meaningful
Projected teaching aids may not enhance learning
Writing big neat handwriting helps in teaching

questions.explanation: Projected aids DO enhance learning.

questions.question: An assessment that is generally carried out at the end of the course to assign students a course grade is called:
questions.explanation: Summative assessment evaluates learning at the end of an instructional unit.

questions.question: In teaching, stimulus variation is done in order to:

options.text: Provide a review of the points of presentation
Maintain interest and attention of the learners, avoid repetitive style

questions.explanation: Stimulus variation captures and sustains attention to prevent boredom.

questions.question: The components of the body of a lesson plan entails the following:

options.text: Topic, level of learners, broad objective
Topic, duration of the lesson, level of the learners
Specific objectives, date, duration of the lesson
Specific objectives, teaching method, evaluation, content, learners activity

questions.explanation: The 'body' contains the matrix of objectives, content, methods, activities, and evaluation.

questions.question: Criterion-referenced assessment is described as:

options.text: An assessment where score is compared with the scores of a group
The assessment carried out at the end of the term
The extent to which an assessment performance is related to another valued measure
An assessment intended to measure how well an individual has learned a specific subject/topic or skill

questions.explanation: Criterion-referenced tests measure performance against fixed criteria, not other students (norm-referenced).

questions.question: Local bacterial infection in a sick young infant aged 1 week up to 2 months is characterized by:

options.text: Pus draining from the ear, fever

questions.explanation: In IMCI, 'Local Bacterial Infection' is indicated by red umbilicus or skin pustules. Convulsions/Fever indicate Very Severe Disease.

questions.question: A child with mumps is best managed by:
questions.explanation: Mumps is viral; management is supportive (fluids, rest, pain relief). Antibiotics are ineffective.

questions.question: Follow-up of a child treated for pneumonia is done after:
questions.explanation: IMCI guidelines require follow-up in 2 days for pneumonia.

questions.question: An infant with confirmed meningitis may be treated with:

options.text: Benzyl penicillin 100,000 units every six hours

questions.explanation: Ceftriaxone is a third-generation cephalosporin of choice for bacterial meningitis due to CSF penetration.

questions.question: Hirschsprung's disease is caused by:

options.text: Absence of ganglion cells precursors in the distal bowel
Imperforate anus due to embryologic defects
Out pouching of the distal ileum

questions.explanation: Hirschsprung's is congenital aganglionic megacolon (absence of ganglion cells).

questions.question: The state in which a mental patient experiences persecutory delusion and excessive grandeur is:
questions.explanation: Paranoid schizophrenia is characterized by prominent delusions of persecution or grandeur.

questions.question: Speech disorders include:

options.text: Presence of speech, flight of ideas, illusion
Pressure of speech, flight of ideas, retardation of speech
Perseveration, flight of ideas, paranoid ideas

questions.explanation: Pressure of speech and retardation are disorders of speech flow/rate. Flight of ideas is thought manifested as speech.

questions.question: Displacement is an ego defense mechanism where the person:

options.text: Replaces unacceptable feelings with their exact opposite
Covers his or her weakness by emphasizing a desirable trait

questions.explanation: Displacement is shifting impulses to a less threatening target.

questions.question: The principles of psychiatric nursing include:

options.text: Empathy, accepting the patient as he is, spontaneity, accountability
Awareness of basic human needs, permissiveness and firmness, creativity
Shared activities, sympathy, empathy, therapeutic relationship
Self-understanding, sympathy, awareness of basic human needs, strictness

questions.explanation: Acceptance and Empathy (not Sympathy) are core principles.

questions.question: The following are the principles of management of substance abuse:

options.text: Detoxification, empathy, awareness of basic human needs
Detoxification, rehabilitation, relapse prevention, after care, social rehabilitation

questions.explanation: Management involves Detox -> Rehab -> Relapse Prevention -> Aftercare.

questions.question: State five (5) specific nursing management steps for an infant with trachea-oesophageal atresia (TEF).
Explain the three (3) major phases of a research proposal.
State four (4) components of an effective research abstract.
Explain three (3) ethical issues in research concerning the subject.
Outline four (4) qualities of an educational objective (SMART).
Outline five (5) disadvantages of simulation as a teaching method.
State five (5) principles of learning.
Using the acronym 'CAGE', identify the questions used in screening for alcoholism.
Case Study: Mr. Z (20yo) with PTSD after terror attack. Select causes, symptoms, and management.
Case Study: Master X (3yo) triage (ETAT+). Select Priority signs and Emergency assessment.

options.text: Triage Def: Rapid screening to identify emergency/priority cases
